channel.title: NYT > World
channel.copyright: Copyright 2013 The New York Times Company

item.title: The Lede: Spanish Train Crash Captured on Video
item.description: Security-camera footage leaked to the public via YouTube captured the moment on Wednesday that a passenger train derailed outside Santiago de Compostela in northwestern Spain, killing at least 80 people.
item.dc:creator: By ROBERT MACKEY and CHRISTINE HAUSER

item.title: The Lede: The Third Man on Snowden’s Reading List
item.description: One of the three books Edward J. Snowden’s Russian lawyer gave him on Wednesday was by Nikolai Karamzin, the court historian to Czar Alexander I who argued two centuries ago that Russia could only thrive under autocratic rule.
item.dc:creator: By ROBERT MACKEY
item.media:description: A portrait of Nikolai Karamzin, the court historian of Czar Alexander I who died in 1826.

item.title: Way of the World: Preparing American Children to Dance With Robots
item.description: A paper argues that schools have not gotten worse, but that education needs to be transformed to meet the demands of a new age.
item.dc:creator: By CHRYSTIA FREELAND | REUTERS

item.title: World Briefing | Asia: Chinese Rights Advocate Is Detained
item.description: Hu Jia, a human rights activist, was held for several hours by the police in the southern city of Shenzhen, along with his daughter and a lawyer.
item.dc:creator: By EDWARD WONG

item.title: World Briefing | Middle East: U.N. Official Asks Israel to Reconsider Bill on Bedouins
item.description: The legislation, which aims to resolve Bedouin landownership claims, could lead to the demolition of villages in the Negev desert.
item.category: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations
item.dc:creator: By NICK CUMMING-BRUCE

item.title: Spanish Train Inquiry Looks at a Driver Obsessed With Speed
item.description: A high-speed passenger train crashed in northwestern Spain on Wednesday night, killing 80 people and leaving at least 100 injured, according to judicial sources and local news reports.
item.dc:creator: By SILVIA TAULÉS and DOREEN CARVAJAL
item.media:credit: Antonio Hernandez/El Correo Gallego, via Associated Press
item.media:description: More than 200 passengers and employees were on the train.

item.title: Taliban Claim Deadly Attack on Pakistani Spy Agency
item.description: At least nine people were killed in an attack on a regional office that again highlighted the militants’ ability to strike sensitive targets.
item.dc:creator: By SALMAN MASOOD

item.title: 2 Koreas Fail to Agree on Terms to Reopen Factory Complex
item.description: The sixth round of talks this month over the project ended without a date for further discussions on the Kaesong industrial park.
item.dc:creator: By CHOE SANG-HUN

item.title: Second Opposition Leader Assassinated in Tunisia
item.description: The killing of Mohamed Brahmi, leader of the People’s Party, incited protests blaming the moderate Islamic party that leads the government in Tunisia, birthplace of the Arab Spring.
item.dc:creator: By CARLOTTA GALL and RICK GLADSTONE
item.media:description: Medical workers carried the body of Mohamed Brahmi, leader of the Arab nationalist People’s Party, on Thursday.

item.title: Prosecutor Calls Manning an Egotist Who Betrayed Nation’s Trust
item.description: The prosecution argues that Pfc. Bradley Manning is a traitor, but his lawyers say he is a principled protester who wanted to help society.
item.dc:creator: By CHARLIE SAVAGE

item.title: Tunisian Opposition Leader Killed, Party Says
item.description: A member of Tunisia’s opposition People’s Movement party says its leader, Mohammed Brahmi, has been shot dead.
item.dc:creator: By THE ASSOCIATED PRESS
item.media:description: People gathered outside a hospital in northern Tunisia after the shooting of Mohammed Brahmi.

item.title: Kerry Visits U.N. to Discuss World Crises
item.description: In his first official visit, the secretary of state talked about turmoil in Africa’s Great Lakes region, the Syrian war and the Israeli-Palestinian conflict.
item.dc:creator: By RICK GLADSTONE

item.title: India Ink: Image of the Day: July 25
item.description: A teacher imparting instruction from the Koran to children at a religious school in New Delhi.
item.dc:creator: By THE NEW YORK TIMES
item.media:description: A teacher offering lessons from the Koran to children at a local religious school in New Delhi.

item.title: UN Chief Says Over 100,000 People Killed in Syria
item.description: Secretary-General Ban Ki-moon on Thursday raised the death toll in Syria's civil war to more than 100,000, up from nearly 93,000 just over a month ago.
item.dc:creator: By THE ASSOCIATED PRESS

item.title: India Ink: Verdict on Juvenile in Delhi Gang Rape Deferred Again
item.description: The Juvenile Justice Board is now expected to give the verdict on August 5.
item.dc:creator: By PAMPOSH RAINA
item.media:description: Policemen in plain clothes escorting the juvenile accused, center with face covered, after the court hearing in New Delhi on Thursday.

item.title: WikiLeaks Founder to Run for Australian Senate
item.description: Questions remain about whether Julian Assange can take office if he wins the election, given that he is holed up in Ecuador’s embassy in London.
item.dc:creator: By MATT SIEGEL
item.media:description: Julian Assange, the founder of WikiLeaks, at the Ecuadorean Embassy in London in June.

item.title: India Ink: An Acid Attack Survivor Helps India Change Its Laws
item.description: The resilience of an Indian acid attack survivor makes the country’s Supreme Court amend India’s criminal law.
item.dc:creator: By HARI KUMAR
item.media:description: Students taking part in a silent protest against the rising violence against women in Kolkata, West Bengal, on July 4.

item.title: Killing Puts Focus on Concerns Over China’s One-Child Policy
item.description: A man with a knife killed two government workers at a family planning bureau after the office refused to register his fourth child for residency.
item.dc:creator: By KEITH BRADSHER

item.title: Fallen Leader Is Indicted in China
item.description: Bo Xilai, who had been expelled from the Communist Party Politburo, was indicted Thursday on bribery and corruption charges. His trial was expected within weeks.
item.category: Politburo Standing Committee of the Communist Party of China
item.dc:creator: By EDWARD WONG and JONATHAN ANSFIELD
item.media:description: Bo Xilai would be the first Politburo member to be tried on criminal charges since 2008.

item.title: World Briefing | The Americas: Mexico: Gunmen Attack Federal Police
item.description: A wave of attacks on the federal police in Michoacán has left at least 24 dead in the past two days, including four officers and 20 gunmen, the authorities said.
item.dc:creator: By KARLA ZABLUDOVSKY

item.title: The Lede: Video of Clashes in Brazil Appears to Show Police Infiltrators Among Protesters
item.description: Supporters of Brazil’s protest movement and the police in Rio de Janeiro argued online over which side was to blame for violence at a demonstration this week.
item.dc:creator: By ROBERT MACKEY, SERGIO PEÇANHA and TAYLOR BARNES and NADIA SUSSMAN
item.media:description: A screenshot from video released by the police in Rio de Janeiro showed a masked man moments before he hurled a Molotov cocktail at officers.

item.title: India Ink: A Kitchen That Prepares Lunch for Schoolchildren in Delhi
item.description: Stri Shakti, a nongovernmental organization, prepares food for about 300,000 children in New Delhi every day.
item.dc:creator: By PAMPOSH RAINA
item.media:description: Workers filling steel containers with rice at the Stri Shakti kitchen in West Delhi.

item.title: Garment Trade Wields Power in Bangladesh
item.description: The industry’s trade group has seen its influence soar in recent years, but critics say the group has helped make the nation dangerous for garment workers.
item.category: Bangladesh Garment Manufacturers and Exporters Assn
item.dc:creator: By JIM YARDLEY
item.media:credit: Taslima Akhter for The New York Times
item.media:description: An office tower built by the garment trade association in Dhaka, Bangladesh, is in legal limbo. A court ordered it demolished.

item.title: World Briefing | Asia: Japan: Jets Scrambled Near Okinawa
item.description: Japanese fighter jets scrambled on Wednesday after a Chinese military plane flew through international airspace near Okinawa, Japan’s defense minister said.
item.dc:creator: By MARTIN FACKLER

item.title: World Briefing | Middle East: Syria: Chemical Arms Experts Arrive
item.description: Two United Nations officials arrived in Syria on Wednesday to discuss the scope of an inquiry into the suspected use of chemical weapons in the war.
item.category: Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )
item.dc:creator: By RICK GLADSTONE
